content: hey everyone why lock here thanks for
joining me well I am not the first and I certainly won't be the last but here is
how I turned a ping-pong ball into a beholder super fun project takes 2 to 3
hours excluding painting gonna walk you through it step-by-step so let's get to
it begin with a standard ping-pong ball draw a circle on it with a sharpie with
a diameter of about 30 millimeters if you look at it top down like this so
it's centered in your view you can see how big the circle is relative to the
diameter of the ball few millimeters less then draw a line cutting it in half
use a knife and carefully carefully cut into the ball and slice away half of the
circle it's helpful to use a sawing motion and then use scissors to do that
straight cut across the middle now look at it from the side and you have this
sort of a pacman thing the curved cut that you just did is going to be the
upper lip so take your scissors now and trim away another slight curve from it
now a cereal box or other decent cardstock of a similar thickness cut a
strip that's 20 millimeters wide and about 60 millimeters long run it through
your fingers to induce a natural curve to it and do a quick dry fit this is
gonna be glued along the bottom curve okay not the upper lip and it's gonna
have about 3 millimeters of contact with the ball the rest of it protrudes out
like this this is the lower jaw if you will so apply a bead of hot glue and
stick it on there a quick lesson learned here glue on the paper side not the
glassy finished side you get much stronger results now this strip is the
lower lip and it follows the curvature of the ball meaning that those two
corners are currently sticking out by pinning them to the ball it's going to
cause the lower lip to flare out very nicely so do that dab of hot glue on
each and a fix them to the ball forming the corners of the mouth now we've got a
decent starting head shape apply hot glue to the inside of the
mouth and tease it back and forth to make some texture in there I don't add
too much hot glue at once because if you have a high temp glue gun it can melt
the ping-pong ball now drawn roughly where the eye is gonna go this first try
was a little too high a second try wasn't totally centered third time's the
charm and I do sort of a dip in the circle at
the top so rather than a perfect circular eye this gives it that menacing
look you often see like its brow is furrowed so then lay a thin bead of hot
glue around the eye following a line that you just drew then start gradually
adding and teasing on hot glue over the entire model this will hide the seams of
that cardstock and give the creature its alien like skin here's a tip don't just
do random streaking I recommend that you go away from the eyeball always working
away from the eyeball so that the texture kind of goes in one direction to
unify on the backside of the ball I will make the eyestalks
this is some costume jewelry a fake pearl necklace small spherical beads
will work just fine too you need 10 of them and then paper clips
these are the kind of paper clips that have a plastic coating on them although
that's not necessary if you do have it use some snips and strip away a few
millimeters of the coating from an end to have a hot glue on the bead and
insert the paper clip and then gradually add an T's hot glue over half of the
bead going down onto the paper clip it's easier to do this bit before you attach
it to the model so there you can see I left half of the beads smooth and bare
to attach pick a spot and poke a hole with a pencil or an awl or a hand drill
whatever you've got then insert the eye stalk and again add an T's hot glue
around the base and working up along the stalk
left over sprues or any plastic bits you can get a hold of really snip at an
extreme angle like this and then attach it near the corner of the mouth it's
helpful to use tweezers to do this I put two on each side from here it's time to
go outside and spray prime this thing that done take a dark magenta sort of
color and do the inside of the mouth had to do this before we attach the teeth
otherwise he could never get a brush in there that said don't waste too much
time on this since it pretty much won't be seen just a solid coat of a deep
color done now for the teeth cut off the tips of toothpicks maybe two to four
millimeters long then lay a thin bead of hot glue along the lip and use tweezers
to install the teeth work quickly is the hot glue cools but if it does just
revisit it with the tip of the hot glue gun to reheat and soften it I found that
I could do two to three teeth at a time before having to go back with the gun to
reheat the glue so once those are all on a final thin bead of hot glue over top
sort of at the base of the teeth to strengthen them and sort of look like
the gums from here you paint this thing as you like and according to your
ability but in a moment I'll walk through exactly how I painted mine and
how I baste it if you dig this video please don't hesitate to hit that like
button give me a sub click the reminder all
that usual junk also and this is really important for my channel there is a way
for you to support me totally free if you want to just use my Amazon
storefront link it's in the video description below first off you see all
the products that I use and recommend but also anything you buy costs the same
delivery is unaffected it's totally transparent to you the only
difference is I get a small kickback for having referred you and for all you 3d
printers out there while ochs crafting goods is sponsored by heroes horde which
has an excellent range of high-quality models including but not limited to
Altru tiles lines which are open lock compatible also check out my modules
over on the DMS guild and remember $3 patrons get free copies of all my
releases so the base colors this is going to be 2
onde beige and blue and a light and dark version of each of those so into the
airbrush with the light beige and a solid base coat over the entire body
number four tips and intro on airbrushing check out episode 90 next is
the light blue I did only the top half of the body including all the eye stocks
and where the transition is in the middle of the body pull the airbrush a
few inches further away from the model this will cast a wider more dispersed
beam and you'll get a more subtle gradual transition where the blue meets
the beige next is a darker blue hitting the top quarter or so randomly hitting
all the eye stocks and finally the darker beige or brown just hit the very
bottom so this is what we got so far transitions are pretty good and I went
with brighter colors because I'm about to wash with shades
whenever you're gonna use washes it's a good idea to do the base coat much
brighter than you think appropriate I'm going to be using army painter blue tone
and soft tone now I find that these army painter washes are very very rich in
pigment which is a great thing I mean they're awesome but they're thick so I
like to mix in some water something a little less than 50/50 anyway apply with
a nice soft brush first I did the blue so satisfying when it hits the detail
and then on the bottom half I applied the soft tone where the two meet at the
waist I just dipped the brush in both and kind of swish it around on that
waistline to kind of blend the two together and here it is wet it's gonna
take about an hour to fully dry but I'm pretty excited with that transition I'm
generally not a miniature painter I mean I enjoy it but it's not like my thing so
trying out more advanced looks like this is pretty exciting for me and here it is
dry now typically what is done at this point is highlighting so maybe some
layering or edge highlighting or even simple dry brushing but I'm pretty happy
with how it looks right now and I don't want to risk messing it up so I'm just
gonna move along first I went back to that same mouth color and painted the
gums and then with a neutral middle gray I did the spikes and also all of the
eyeballs gray is a great under color for yellows and beiges so take the
opportunity now to make life easier then with a black wash such as army
painter black tone shade the gums and the spice and now for the eyes first I
took a bone and a white and I mixed them 5050 base coated the surface of the
eyeballs remember two thin coats is the way to do it then with a bronze ish sort
of orange a free hand to the outer iris it's kind of a pedal shape like this
and same thing on the smaller I stocks
next up a plain yellow and on the main large I paint a smaller version of that
pedal inside the orange don't bother with the yellow for the smaller eyes and
then with black a thin line down the middle of the irises I awry IRA sees
irises and then with the finest tip brush that you have thin red capillaries
at the edges of the eyes just short jagged lines coming in from the
perimeter oh and I just remembered I forgot to edge highlight those spikes so
take a lighter gray and do that then back to that army painters soft tone or
any light brown wash this is a controlled recessed shade at the edges
of all the eyes to kind of blend them into the flesh around them hide the gap
and lastly optional a gloss varnish over the surface of olive a balls the model
itself is now done and at the end I'm going to show it to you in context on
some tiles and stuff but I thought about how to base it I found these disposable
plastic champagne flutes at the dollar store this is the bottom of one of those
flutes and I've actually used it before on some other project but I tore it off
so I could show it to you here I would just use hot glue to attach it to the
model so it looks pretty good the base is a two and a half inch diameter which
is a bit too large but if you're a fanatic about clear bases this might be
a way to go I do not care about clear bases so I got
these drink stirring sticks also at the dollar store
and we're gonna use this to mount the model to for the base itself amusing
chipboard if you're new here I use this all the time on the channel it's
graphics medium chipboard again there's a link in the video description below
but alternatively this is the brownish grayish slab that you find at the back
of a legal pad just harvest some that way anyway draw and cut out a two inch
circle since the beholder is a large creature after all and then chop the
stirrer however high you want the beholder to be floating I'm just gonna
do about an inch and hot glue it to the center of the circle apply white PVA
glue such as Elmer's to the base and flock with sand and pebbles a couple
hours that's bone dry and apply a solid base coat of black and after that's bone
dry I'm just gonna do a dry brush with a neutral gray easy
from here I had to decide how to mount it to the post and I could drill in the
bottom and stick the pole in glue it I don't know I just for some reason I just
didn't want to do that so very simply a dollop of hot glue on top of the post
and then quickly mount the beholder on it this is not the strongest connection
in the world at all I mean the glue is directly on paint but I mean it's fine
for tabletop gaming this doesn't have to be earthquake-proof so there now let's
go check it out on a table and we're more appropriate to visit then the
Underdark so here are the Underdark style tiles from episode 120 and the
scatter from episode 124 and I just got a layout set up here with a few paper
miniature heroes fly on down for a heroes level view so this dude is here
in his lair garden something or another now when I do episodes usually I make
two of a thing one is to learn how to make it and the second is once I'm
efficient I remake it and film it here is a second beholder that I made he was
inspired by what you usually see on the covers of books that more reddish-brown
sort of appearance here's some pictures of him under development so I got a
beige base coat and then that bronze orange gradient on the top half and then
a red on top of that so this is just a three color gradient and some things
that is different so with him I just gave him a strong tone wash where a grex
a shade just a brown wash over the entire thing as opposed to using two
colors and then also the gums I didn't revisit them actually I forgot and I
actually liked to look better I kind of wish I hadn't done that on the blue one
and one more close-up with a blue one I am pretty happy with how these turned
out normally I can do architecture straight lines tiles and pillars and
stuff all day long creatures organic stuff it escapes me I
just it's not my forte so these just sort of happened over the
course of a day or two they take about two hours to make so you can make an
army of bee holders if you want to if you're new to this whole scene and you
suddenly feel compelled to buy an airbrush again recommends are down in my
storefront and I hope you'll find us on the tabletop crafters guild on facebook
27,000 members strong and growing if you liked this particular project here's two
more that you should go check out right now also enjoy this
community showcase and don't forget to subscribe and click that Bell reminder
icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll see you next time
you
